description: Understand place value through thousandths; read, write, compare, and round decimals; perform basic decimal operations

coreConcepts: Place value names through thousandths
Comparing decimals by aligning place values
Rounding to a given place
Adding/subtracting decimals with alignment
commonMistakes: Thinking 0.12 > 0.9 because 12 > 9
Forgetting to align decimal points when adding/subtracting
Dropping trailing zeros when comparing (0.5 vs 0.50)
teachingTips: Use money: $0.50 vs $0.05 makes place value real
Grid models work well for decimal comparison
Connect to measurement: meters and centimeters

description: Review adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing fractions and mixed numbers from 5th grade

coreConcepts: LCD for adding/subtracting unlike fractions
Multiplying fractions straight across and simplifying
Dividing fractions by reciprocal
Mixed number operations
commonMistakes: Adding numerators AND denominators (1/3 + 1/4 ≠ 2/7)
Forgetting to find LCD before adding unlike fractions
Not converting mixed numbers to improper fractions before multiplying/dividing
teachingTips: Use fraction strips and area models before going symbolic
Cooking/recipe contexts make fraction operations tangible
Always require simplification to lowest terms

description: Understand positive and negative numbers on the number line; compare and order integers

coreConcepts: Integers include positive, negative, and zero
Number line extends left (negative) and right (positive)
Comparing integers: farther right = greater
Opposite of a number: same distance from zero, opposite side
commonMistakes: Thinking -3 > -1 because 3 > 1
Confusing 'bigger number' with 'greater value' for negatives
Placing negatives on the wrong side of the number line
teachingTips: Temperature is the best first context: -5°F is colder than -2°F
Elevator model: below ground = negative floors
Vertical number lines work well alongside horizontal ones

description: Fluency with multi-digit multiplication and long division; automaticity with basic multiplication facts

coreConcepts: Multiplication facts through 12×12 on autopilot
Standard algorithm for multi-digit multiplication
Long division with multi-digit divisors
Estimating quotients before dividing
commonMistakes: Misaligned partial products in multiplication
Skipping the estimation step in long division
Fact gaps (6×7, 8×9) that slow everything down
teachingTips: Diagnose fact gaps first — no fluency without facts
Use area model for multiplication to build understanding alongside the algorithm
Connect division to 'how many groups' and 'how many in each group'

description: Translate word phrases into numerical and simple algebraic expressions; connect words to math operations

coreConcepts: Key words: sum/total → add, difference → subtract, product → multiply, quotient → divide
Order matters for subtraction and division
Using parentheses to show grouping
Simple variable usage: 'a number' → n
commonMistakes: Reversing order: '5 less than x' written as 5 - x instead of x - 5
Missing parentheses: 'twice the sum of 3 and x' = 2(3 + x), not 2·3 + x
Thinking every word problem maps to addition
teachingTips: Start with 'math to words' before 'words to math' — it's easier to describe what you see
Use 'less than' vs 'minus' to highlight order sensitivity
Build a reference chart of key phrases and their operations

description: Divide multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm fluently

coreConcepts: Standard long division algorithm
Estimating quotients to check reasonableness
Division with remainders expressed as fractions or decimals
Interpreting remainders in context (round up, round down, remainder only)
commonMistakes: Skipping place values in the quotient (forgetting to write 0)
Not bringing down the next digit
Interpreting remainders incorrectly in word problems
teachingTips: Connect to real contexts: splitting items evenly, packaging, seating arrangements
Practice with 2-digit divisors extensively before moving on

description: Divide decimals by whole numbers and by decimals using the standard algorithm; includes converting divisor to whole number

coreConcepts: Dividing a decimal by a whole number: place decimal in quotient directly above
Dividing by a decimal: multiply both by power of 10 to make divisor whole
Annexing zeros when needed
Estimating to check reasonableness
commonMistakes: Misplacing the decimal point in the quotient
Forgetting to move BOTH decimal points when dividing by a decimal
Not annexing zeros to continue dividing past the decimal point
teachingTips: Money context: $12.75 ÷ 3 = how much per person
Always estimate first to catch decimal placement errors
Connect to unit rates: $5.40 for 4 pounds = $? per pound

description: Add and subtract fractions and mixed numbers with unlike denominators fluently

coreConcepts: Finding the LCD (least common denominator)
Rewriting fractions with the LCD
Adding/subtracting numerators while keeping the common denominator
Simplifying results and converting improper fractions to mixed numbers
commonMistakes: Adding denominators: 1/3 + 1/4 ≠ 2/7
Using a common denominator that isn't the LCD (works but creates bigger numbers)
Not simplifying the final answer
Borrowing errors with mixed numbers (3 1/4 - 1 3/4)
teachingTips: Fraction strips for visualization, then transition to algorithm
Use recipe doubling/halving for real-world practice
Drill LCD-finding as a separate skill before combining with operations

description: Multiply and divide fractions and mixed numbers; interpret division of fractions in context

coreConcepts: Multiply: multiply numerators, multiply denominators, simplify
Cross-canceling before multiplying to keep numbers small
Divide: multiply by the reciprocal (Keep-Change-Flip)
Interpret fraction division: how many 1/3-cup servings in 2 cups?
commonMistakes: Finding common denominators to multiply (not needed)
Flipping the wrong fraction when dividing
Not converting mixed numbers to improper fractions before operating
teachingTips: Area models show WHY multiplying fractions gives a smaller result
Division: 'how many groups of ___ fit in ___?' makes the operation concrete
Always require context interpretation, not just computation

description: Find the greatest common factor and least common multiple using listing, prime factorization, or the ladder method; apply to real-world problems

coreConcepts: GCF: largest number that divides evenly into both numbers
LCM: smallest number that both numbers divide into evenly
Listing method: list factors/multiples and find the greatest/least overlap
Distributive property connection: GCF(a,b) lets you write a+b = GCF(a+b/GCF, ...)
commonMistakes: Confusing GCF and LCM (GCF of 12 and 8 is 4, LCM is 24)
Stopping at any common factor instead of the GREATEST
Forgetting that 1 is always a common factor
teachingTips: GCF = sharing/grouping contexts (splitting into equal groups, packaging)
LCM = scheduling contexts (two buses that leave every 12 and 8 minutes)
Venn diagram with prime factors works great for both

description: Use ratio language (a:b, a to b, a/b) to describe relationships between two quantities; distinguish part-to-part from part-to-whole

coreConcepts: Three ways to write a ratio: 3:5, 3 to 5, 3/5
Part-to-part (boys to girls) vs part-to-whole (boys to total)
Order matters: 3:5 ≠ 5:3
Ratios describe a relationship, not a specific amount
commonMistakes: Confusing ratio with fraction (ratio 3:5 is not always 3/5 of something)
Reversing the order of the ratio
Forgetting to specify what each number represents
teachingTips: Start with concrete: 'In this bag, there are 4 red and 6 blue marbles'
Color-coding helps: write each quantity in a different color
Have students create ratios from classroom objects

description: Find and use unit rates (price per item, miles per hour, words per minute); compare using unit rates

coreConcepts: Unit rate = amount per 1 unit (divide to find it)
The word 'per' signals a unit rate
Compare options by finding the unit rate for each
Both rates in a ratio can produce useful unit rates
commonMistakes: Dividing in the wrong direction (price ÷ items vs items ÷ price)
Confusing 'per ounce' with 'per dollar'
Not specifying units in the answer
teachingTips: Grocery store unit pricing is the perfect real-world anchor
Speed (mph) and pay rate ($/hour) are instantly relatable
Always require the unit label in the answer — 'per what?'

description: Generate equivalent ratios using multiplication/division; complete and extend ratio tables

coreConcepts: Equivalent ratios: multiply or divide both quantities by the same number
Ratio tables show the pattern of equivalent ratios
Double number lines as a visual model
Simplifying ratios (like simplifying fractions)
commonMistakes: Adding the same number to both sides instead of multiplying
Skipping rows in a ratio table and losing the pattern
Not checking that the multiplier is consistent across the table
teachingTips: Recipe scaling is the ideal context — double, triple, halve a recipe
Ratio tables should always include at least 4 rows to show the pattern
Connect to fractions: equivalent ratios work like equivalent fractions

description: Solve real-world ratio and rate problems using tables, diagrams, and equivalent ratios

coreConcepts: Identify the ratio relationship in a word problem
Choose a strategy: ratio table, unit rate, or scale factor
Check the answer against the original ratio
Multi-step ratio problems (find the rate, then use it)
commonMistakes: Setting up the ratio backwards
Using additive reasoning instead of multiplicative
Not reading the question — answering what they found, not what was asked
teachingTips: Teach multiple strategies and let students choose
Travel problems (distance/time), shopping problems (cost/quantity), mixing problems (concentrate/water)
Require students to set up the ratio BEFORE computing

description: Convert measurement units within a system (inches to feet, grams to kilograms) using ratio reasoning

coreConcepts: Conversion as a ratio: 1 foot = 12 inches → 1:12 ratio
Multiply to go from larger to smaller units
Divide to go from smaller to larger units
Common conversions: inches/feet/yards, ounces/pounds, mL/L, cm/m/km
commonMistakes: Multiplying when they should divide (or vice versa)
Confusing metric and customary units
Not knowing the basic conversion factors
teachingTips: Frame as ratio problems: 'If 1 foot = 12 inches, then 3.5 feet = ?'
Use ratio tables for conversions — same structure, new context
Focus on the conversions students will actually encounter (cooking, sports, building)

description: Translate verbal phrases and real-world situations into algebraic expressions with variables, numbers, and operations

coreConcepts: Variables represent unknown or changing quantities
Match operations to context words (sum, difference, product, quotient, twice, each)
Use parentheses to show grouping when needed
Expressions can have multiple operations and variables
commonMistakes: Reversing subtraction/division order: '8 less than n' → n - 8, NOT 8 - n
Missing parentheses: 'double the sum of x and 3' → 2(x + 3), NOT 2x + 3
Using the wrong operation for the context
teachingTips: Practice both directions: words → expression AND expression → words
Use student-generated scenarios for buy-in
Create a 'key phrase' reference sheet and retire it once fluent

description: Substitute values for variables and evaluate expressions using order of operations

coreConcepts: Replace each variable with its value (use parentheses around the substituted value)
Apply order of operations (GEMS) strictly
Evaluate expressions with one and two variables
Check by substituting back if solving
commonMistakes: Not using parentheses when substituting (especially negatives)
Left-to-right errors with multiplication/division or addition/subtraction
Forgetting that 2x means 2 × x, not 2 next to x
teachingTips: Always write the substitution step: if x=3, write 2(3)+5, not just 11
Use tables: 'Evaluate 3x + 1 for x = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4' to show patterns
Connect to function machines: input → rule → output

description: Combine like terms, apply the distributive property, and use associative and commutative properties to simplify expressions

coreConcepts: Like terms: same variable raised to the same power (3x and 5x are like; 3x and 3x² are not)
Combine by adding/subtracting coefficients
Distributive property: a(b + c) = ab + ac
Commutative/associative properties to rearrange and group
commonMistakes: Combining unlike terms: 3x + 5y ≠ 8xy
Distributing only to the first term: 2(x + 3) ≠ 2x + 3
Forgetting that x means 1x
teachingTips: Algebra tiles make combining like terms visual and tangible
Color-code like terms to help students identify them
Practice distributive property with mental math first: 7 × 98 = 7(100-2) = 700-14 = 686

description: Identify and name parts of expressions: terms, coefficients, constants, and factors

coreConcepts: Term: a part of an expression separated by + or -
Coefficient: the number multiplied by the variable
Constant: a term with no variable
Factor: numbers/variables multiplied together within a term
commonMistakes: Confusing coefficient with constant
Not recognizing that x has a coefficient of 1
Miscounting terms when subtraction is involved (a - b has 2 terms, not 1)
teachingTips: Label expressions like a diagram — circle terms, underline coefficients, box constants
Use 'expression anatomy' as an activity
Connect to real-world: in 5x + 3, the 5 is the rate and 3 is the starting value

description: Use standard formulas to calculate area and volume; substitute values into formulas and solve for a variable (light intro)

coreConcepts: A formula is an equation showing a relationship (A = lw, V = lwh)
Substitution: replace variables with known values and compute
Solving for a missing dimension: if A = 24 and l = 6, then w = ?
Units: area in square units, volume in cubic units
commonMistakes: Confusing area and perimeter formulas
Forgetting to square the units for area
Plugging values into the wrong variable
teachingTips: Start with rectangles/rectangular prisms before triangles
Use physical objects: area of a desk, volume of a shoebox
Connect to expressions: A = lw is just an expression with two variables

description: Solve one-step and two-step equations using inverse operations; verify solutions by substitution

coreConcepts: Equation = a balance scale — whatever you do to one side, do to the other
Inverse operations: addition ↔ subtraction, multiplication ↔ division
Box the variable term: outside the box use opposites, inside the box divide it out
Always check by substituting the answer back
commonMistakes: Performing the same operation instead of the inverse
In two-step equations, dividing before subtracting (order matters)
Forgetting to check the solution
teachingTips: Balance scale model is essential — physical or virtual
Start with 'guess and check' to build intuition, then formalize with inverse operations
Cover equations with fractions and decimals, not just whole numbers

description: Conceptual introduction to equations with variables on both sides; understand why we collect variables to one side

coreConcepts: If both sides have the variable, collect to one side by subtracting
Balance scale still applies — same operation on both sides
Some equations have no solution or infinite solutions (conceptual only)
This is a preview — full mastery comes in 7th grade
commonMistakes: Subtracting the variable from the wrong side
Not recognizing that 2x + 3 = 2x + 7 has no solution
Trying to combine terms across the equals sign without moving them first
teachingTips: Keep this light — only simple examples like 3x + 2 = x + 10
Use the balance scale with x-tiles on both sides
Frame as a 'sneak peek' of 7th-grade algebra to build confidence

description: Write, solve, graph, and interpret inequalities; understand that inequalities have infinitely many solutions

coreConcepts: Inequality symbols: < > ≤ ≥ ≠
An inequality has infinitely many solutions (unlike an equation)
Graphing on a number line: open circle (< >) vs closed circle (≤ ≥)
Writing inequalities from context: 'at least', 'no more than', 'fewer than'
commonMistakes: Confusing < and > direction (alligator eats the bigger number)
Using closed circle for strict inequalities or vice versa
Thinking there's only one answer to an inequality
teachingTips: Real-world constraints are great: 'You must be at least 48 inches tall' → h ≥ 48
Have students generate 3 solutions and 3 non-solutions for each inequality
Connect open/closed circles to 'included' (≤ ≥) vs 'not included' (< >)

description: Build equations and inequalities from real-world word problems; solve and interpret solutions in context

coreConcepts: Read the problem, identify what's unknown (= the variable)
Translate the relationship into an equation or inequality
Solve and check — does the answer make sense in context?
Some problems require two-step thinking
commonMistakes: Jumping to computation without setting up the equation first
Choosing the wrong operation from context clues
Finding the mathematical answer but not interpreting it (remainder, rounding)
teachingTips: Teach a structured approach: 1) Define variable, 2) Write equation, 3) Solve, 4) Check in context
Use 'numberless word problems' to focus on structure before computation
Mix in problems where students write their OWN word problem from a given equation

description: Calculate the area of triangles and parallelograms by connecting to rectangle area; use A = bh and A = ½bh

coreConcepts: Parallelogram area = base × height (same as rectangle when you 'cut and slide')
Triangle area = ½ × base × height (half of the parallelogram)
Height is PERPENDICULAR to the base — not the slanted side
Any side can be the base — the height changes accordingly
commonMistakes: Using the slant height instead of the perpendicular height
Forgetting the ½ in triangle area
Confusing base with the longest side (base is whichever side you choose)
teachingTips: Cut a parallelogram from paper, rearrange into a rectangle — they SEE it
Two congruent triangles form a parallelogram — show this physically
Grid paper helps students count square units to verify formulas

description: Find the area of figures composed of triangles, rectangles, and other polygons by decomposing them

coreConcepts: Break complex shapes into simpler shapes (rectangles + triangles)
Calculate each part separately, then add
Sometimes it's easier to find a big shape and subtract a missing piece
Label all dimensions before computing
commonMistakes: Double-counting shared edges
Missing a piece of the decomposition
Using wrong dimensions for the sub-shapes
teachingTips: Draw the decomposition lines ON the figure before computing anything
Use real floor plans or room layouts as context
Practice both 'add pieces' and 'subtract the hole' strategies

description: Identify and draw nets of 3D figures; calculate surface area of rectangular prisms and triangular prisms

coreConcepts: A net is a 2D pattern that folds into a 3D shape
Surface area = sum of all face areas
Rectangular prism: 6 faces, 3 pairs of congruent rectangles
SA = 2lw + 2lh + 2wh (or calculate each face individually)
commonMistakes: Forgetting a face (especially the top or bottom)
Counting a face twice or missing a pair
Confusing surface area with volume
teachingTips: Cut out nets and physically fold them — cereal boxes are perfect
For rectangular prisms, color-code the 3 pairs of matching faces
Connect to real-world: wrapping a gift = finding surface area

description: Calculate the volume of right rectangular prisms including with fractional edge lengths; V = lwh

coreConcepts: Volume = length × width × height (how many unit cubes fit inside)
Volume with fractions: same formula, requires fraction multiplication
Pack with fractional unit cubes: 1/2-inch cubes can fill a box with half-inch dimensions
Volume in cubic units (in³, cm³, ft³)
commonMistakes: Confusing surface area and volume formulas
Forgetting cubic units (writing ft² instead of ft³)
Fraction multiplication errors when edges are fractional
teachingTips: Build prisms from unit cubes first, then transition to formula
For fractional edges: 'How many ½-inch cubes fit in a 2½ × 3 × 1½ box?'
Real-world: aquariums, moving boxes, shipping containers

description: Apply area, surface area, and volume to real-world problems: packaging, storage, rooms, construction

coreConcepts: Choose the right measure: area for covering, surface area for wrapping, volume for filling
Multi-step problems: find the area, THEN calculate cost per square foot
Interpret results in context and use appropriate units
Composite 3D problems (L-shaped rooms, buildings)
commonMistakes: Choosing area when the problem asks for volume (or vice versa)
Forgetting to convert units before multiplying
Not answering the actual question (finding area but not the cost)
teachingTips: Assign real projects: design a room, plan a garden, calculate paint needed
Always end with 'So what does this number mean in the real world?'
Mix area + volume in the same problem to force students to distinguish them

description: Distinguish statistical questions from non-statistical questions; understand that statistical questions expect variability in data

coreConcepts: A statistical question anticipates variability in answers
Non-statistical: 'How old am I?' Statistical: 'How old are the students in my class?'
Statistical questions lead to data collection
The variability IS the interesting part — not a problem to eliminate
commonMistakes: Thinking any question with numbers is statistical
Confusing a statistical question with a survey question
Not recognizing that one-answer questions aren't statistical
teachingTips: Have students sort questions into statistical vs non-statistical
Generate both types from the same topic: 'How tall is the teacher?' vs 'How tall are 6th graders?'
Connect to why we need graphs and measures — because the data varies

description: Create and interpret dot plots, histograms, and box plots; choose the appropriate display for a data set

coreConcepts: Dot plot: each data point represented by a dot on a number line
Histogram: data grouped into intervals (bins), bar height = frequency
Box plot: five-number summary (min, Q1, median, Q3, max)
Each display shows different information — choice depends on the question
commonMistakes: Gaps between histogram bars (there shouldn't be any for continuous data)
Confusing histogram bars with bar graphs (histograms show intervals, bar graphs show categories)
Not ordering data before creating a box plot
teachingTips: Start with dot plots — most intuitive
For box plots, build from the five-number summary step by step
Use the same data set in all three displays to compare what each reveals

description: Calculate and interpret mean, median, and mode; understand range and IQR as measures of spread

coreConcepts: Mean: sum ÷ count (the 'fair share' value)
Median: middle value when ordered (resistant to outliers)
Range: max - min (simplest measure of spread)
IQR: Q3 - Q1 (spread of the middle 50%, less affected by outliers)
commonMistakes: Forgetting to order data before finding the median
Not knowing what to do with an even number of data points (average the two middle)
Confusing mean and median — especially when outliers are present
teachingTips: Mean = 'leveling off' — if everyone shared equally, how much would each person get?
Use salary data to show when median is better than mean (CEO outlier effect)
Physical activity: students line up by height, find the median by eliminating from both ends

description: Describe and compare data distributions using shape (symmetric, skewed), center (mean, median), and spread (range, IQR)

coreConcepts: Shape: symmetric (balanced), skewed left/right (tail direction), clusters, gaps
Compare centers: 'Class A's median is higher than Class B's'
Compare spreads: 'Class A has a wider range, meaning more variability'
Use evidence from graphs AND numbers to support claims
commonMistakes: Describing only center without mentioning spread (or vice versa)
Making claims without citing specific numbers as evidence
Confusing skew direction (skewed right = tail goes right, NOT peak goes right)
teachingTips: Always require a claim + evidence format: 'Class A did better because the median was 85 vs 78'
Side-by-side box plots are the best tool for comparison
Use sports data, test scores, or survey results for engaging contexts

description: Use positive and negative numbers to represent real-world quantities: temperature, elevation, money, sea level

coreConcepts: Positive = above/gain/deposit/rise; Negative = below/loss/withdrawal/drop
Zero is the reference point (sea level, ground floor, no change)
Context determines meaning: -$50 is a withdrawal or debt, +$50 is a deposit or credit
Vertical and horizontal number lines both work for representing signed numbers
commonMistakes: Forgetting that zero is neither positive nor negative
Not connecting the sign to the context (just computing without interpreting)
Assuming negative always means 'bad'
teachingTips: Temperature is the most intuitive context for most students
Bank account: deposits (+) and withdrawals (-) with a running balance
Elevation: sea level = 0, mountains = positive, ocean floor = negative

description: Compare and order positive and negative integers, fractions, and decimals on a number line

coreConcepts: On the number line: farther right = greater
For negatives: farther from zero = LESS (more negative)
Use < > = symbols correctly: -5 < -2 < 0 < 3
Convert to the same form (all decimals or all fractions) to compare mixed types
commonMistakes: Thinking -10 > -3 because 10 > 3
Comparing a negative fraction to a positive decimal without converting
Placing negatives on the wrong side of zero on the number line
teachingTips: Number line is the essential tool — draw it every time
Temperature context: 'Is -8°F colder or warmer than -3°F?'
Practice ordering sets of 5-6 mixed rational numbers

description: Understand absolute value as distance from zero; find opposites of numbers; use |x| notation

coreConcepts: Absolute value = distance from zero (always non-negative)
|5| = 5 and |-5| = 5 (both are 5 units from zero)
Opposite of a number: same distance, other side of zero
Opposite of -3 is 3; opposite of 7 is -7
commonMistakes: Thinking absolute value always 'makes it positive' (technically it measures distance)
Confusing -|5| = -5 with |-5| = 5
Not understanding that |0| = 0
teachingTips: Walk a number line physically — steps from zero in either direction
Real-world: 'How far from home?' doesn't care about direction
Use contexts where only magnitude matters: 'How much did it change?' vs 'In which direction?'

description: Plot and identify ordered pairs in all four quadrants; understand the axes, origin, and quadrant system

coreConcepts: Ordered pair (x, y): x = horizontal position, y = vertical position
Four quadrants: I (+,+), II (−,+), III (−,−), IV (+,−)
Origin is (0, 0); axes are the dividing lines
Plot by starting at origin: go right/left for x, then up/down for y
commonMistakes: Reversing x and y in the ordered pair
Going up/down first instead of right/left
Plotting (3, -2) in the wrong quadrant
teachingTips: 'Over and up' mantra: x first (horizontal), y second (vertical)
Quadrant sign patterns: memorize I=(+,+), then rotate counterclockwise
Battleship is a great game for coordinate plane practice

description: Calculate horizontal and vertical distances between points using absolute value; reflect points across axes

coreConcepts: Horizontal distance: |x₁ - x₂| (same y-coordinate)
Vertical distance: |y₁ - y₂| (same x-coordinate)
Reflection across x-axis: (x, y) → (x, -y)
Reflection across y-axis: (x, y) → (-x, y)
commonMistakes: Subtracting coordinates in the wrong order and getting a negative distance
Trying to find diagonal distances (not required at this level)
Confusing which coordinate changes in reflection across x-axis vs y-axis
teachingTips: Count grid squares first, then connect to the absolute value formula
For reflections: fold paper across the axis to show symmetry
Real-world: city blocks (taxicab distance), map coordinates

description: Solve multi-step problems that combine ratios, fractions, and equations; integrate skills from multiple units

coreConcepts: Identify which skills a problem requires before starting
Multi-step problems: break into smaller steps
Check reasonableness at each step
Connect different representations: ratio table → equation → solution
commonMistakes: Solving only part of the problem
Not identifying the right operation from context
Carrying errors forward through multiple steps
teachingTips: Use 'What do I know? What do I need to find? What's my plan?' framework
Mix problem types so students practice identifying the skill needed
Encourage estimation before exact computation

description: Understand percent as a rate per 100; find simple percent of a number; connect percent to fractions and decimals

coreConcepts: Percent means 'per 100': 25% = 25/100 = 0.25
The trio: fraction ↔ decimal ↔ percent (master all three conversions)
Finding percent of a number: 30% of 80 = 0.30 × 80 = 24
Common benchmarks: 10%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%
commonMistakes: Moving the decimal point the wrong direction when converting
Confusing 'percent of' with 'percent increase/decrease' (6th grade is just 'percent of')
Thinking 150% is impossible (it's not — it's 1.5 times)
teachingTips: Start with the benchmarks: 50% is half, 25% is a quarter, 10% is easy division
Bar models: shade parts of a 100-grid to visualize percents
Connect to ratios: 30% = 30 out of 100 = 3 out of 10

description: Convert measurement units across and within systems; apply to multi-step problems with tables and diagrams

coreConcepts: Conversion as ratio reasoning: set up as equivalent ratios
Customary: inches/feet/yards/miles, ounces/pounds/tons, cups/pints/quarts/gallons
Metric: mm/cm/m/km, mL/L, g/kg
Multi-step conversions: convert through an intermediate unit
commonMistakes: Multiplying when dividing is needed (larger unit → fewer of them)
Mixing up customary and metric conversion factors
Not including units in the answer
teachingTips: Ratio tables make conversion systematic
Focus on the conversions students encounter: cooking, distance, weight
Use 'dimensional analysis' lite: write units and cancel

description: Solve complex, multi-step problems using tables, diagrams, and reasoning across multiple mathematical domains

coreConcepts: Read complex problems and identify the sub-questions
Organize information in tables or diagrams before computing
Use multiple tools: ratios, equations, measurement, geometry
Justify the answer in context — 'So what does this mean?'
commonMistakes: Getting overwhelmed by multi-step problems and giving up
Not organizing the information before diving into computation
Answering a sub-question but forgetting to answer the actual question
teachingTips: Teach explicit problem decomposition: 'What's step 1? Step 2?'
Use performance tasks: plan a party, design a garden, calculate a road trip
This is the bridge to 7th-grade math — celebrate the complexity
